title: Seasonal Allergies Can Take a Serious Toll

content: When Eric Huddleston gets home from work each day, if it’s pollen season, he leaves most of his clothes on the front porch before going inside and heading straight for the shower. But that just reduces his exposure to one allergen. Once he’s inside, Huddleston has to face dust and the rescue cat that lives in the basement. “It’s worse in the spring in pollen season, but I have fall allergies, too, and the cat and dust allergies are year-round,” Huddleston says. “So it’s like you’re chronically sick.” For those who don’t live with seasonal allergies, it may seem like a runny nose and itchy, watery eyes would be no big deal, but “even if it’s just these two symptoms, it’s going to affect your concentration, your ability to work, your sleep, and your overall quality of life,” says Deepti Manian, MD, an allergist and immunologist in Topeka, Kansas.

sections.heading: The Burden of Allergy Symptoms
content: When you’re struggling to breathe, it can have far-reaching effects on every aspect of your life.

content_blocks.text: When you’re struggling to breathe, it can have far-reaching effects on every aspect of your life.

sections.heading: Headaches and sinus/ear infections
content: It’s hard to do anything when you are sneezing, blowing your nose, or blinking back tears all day, so work and school are very likely to take a hit. Sinus pressure caused by allergy symptoms can lead to pressure in the head, which causes headaches, and the ears, which can become sore and achy, too. When congestion goes on for too long, it can lead to sinus infections (sinusitis) and ear infections. “Everything in our head is interconnected,” Manian says. “The sinuses drain into the nose, the eyes drain into the nose, the ears drain into the nose, and it all goes down to the throat.” Ear and sinus infections were old hat for Nicole Levin, who teaches English as a second language at an elementary school in New York City. “Before I started doing the double antihistamines that my doctor recommended, it was always sinus infections and ear infections.” She goes to the ear, nose, and throat specialist to have her sinuses and ears drained every three weeks during allergy season. “It helps a lot. Before that, I was really suffering.”

sections.heading: Tightness, coughing and wheezing
content: Seasonal allergies can trigger or worsen asthma symptoms , too. “Some patients who are triggered by pollen may also get chest tightness, wheezing, and coughing during pollen season,” says Priya Patel, MD, an allergist and immunologist at Penn Medicine in Philadelphia, “because the same things that are triggering inflammation in the upper airways are triggering it in the lower airways, too.” Trouble sleeping Seasonal allergies trigger asthma symptoms for Levin, which then keep her up through the night, contributing to the rough can’t-breathe-can’t-sleep cycle that many people with allergies know all too well. But antihistamines can be a double-edged sword, Levin says. They can knock her out so hard that she’s still groggy and “off” throughout the next day at work. She also happens to be allergic to polyethylene glycol , which is found in the coating of many pills. So when she reaches for something to ease her symptoms, she has to be choosy. But without them, there’s no hope of sleep, and then she can’t go to work at all.

But antihistamines can be a double-edged sword, Levin says. They can knock her out so hard that she’s still groggy and “off” throughout the next day at work. content: “When I don’t sleep, I’m in no shape to go to work and deal with children,” Levin says. Sleep is a major challenge for Huddleston during allergy season, too. His sleep apnea adds an extra layer of complication. “When my nose is stuffed up, I can’t use my CPAP and then I really don’t sleep, so I’m just tired all the time,” he says.

content_blocks.text: “When I don’t sleep, I’m in no shape to go to work and deal with children,” Levin says. Sleep is a major challenge for Huddleston during allergy season, too. His sleep apnea adds an extra layer of complication. “When my nose is stuffed up, I can’t use my CPAP and then I really don’t sleep, so I’m just tired all the time,” he says.

sections.heading: Other Allergies
content: People with seasonal allergies tend to be allergic to other things, too. Levin, like Huddleston, is also allergic to dust. Mold bothers her, too. And as winters get warmer, she says, what was once allergy season now seems to last the entire year. “It’s been so warm in the winter that ragweed doesn’t go away and mold doesn’t freeze,” she says. As for Huddleston, when he underwent skin testing for allergies, he says his whole arm turned red, meaning he was allergic to most of what his doctor tested for. But he also has a soft spot in his heart for animals. So when a stray cat showed up at his front door, he and his wife decided to give up their basement to the little fella. The strategy of keeping their furry friend in the basement seems to work, but Huddleston has his limits when it comes to cats. After a visit to the home of a relative who has two cats, Huddleston had to go to the hospital for treatment with a nebulizer containing the asthma medication albuterol . Now he has a nebulizer at home.

sections.heading: Social Stigma
content: People with allergies may also deal with social stigma heightened by the COVID-19 pandemic. Since then, a sneeze is more likely to be met with a “How dare you?” than a “God bless you.” “When you sneeze, everyone looks at you with this look on their face, like ‘Do you have COVID?’” Huddleston says. He’s constantly offering co-workers and students reassurances that it’s only allergies. But sometimes he feels like he should just stay home out of courtesy to others who can’t understand that he’s not spreading a contagious virus. “Some people with seasonal allergies have to do multiple COVID tests because their work requires it, and since COVID, seasonal allergies have really impacted people’s social lives,” Manian says.

content_blocks.text: People with allergies may also deal with social stigma heightened by the COVID-19 pandemic. Since then, a sneeze is more likely to be met with a “How dare you?” than a “God bless you.” “When you sneeze, everyone looks at you with this look on their face, like ‘Do you have COVID?’” Huddleston says. He’s constantly offering co-workers and students reassurances that it’s only allergies. But sometimes he feels like he should just stay home out of courtesy to others who can’t understand that he’s not spreading a contagious virus. “Some people with seasonal allergies have to do multiple COVID tests because their work requires it, and since COVID, seasonal allergies have really impacted people’s social lives,” Manian says.

sections.heading: How to Treat Seasonal Allergies
content: A doctor may suggest a stepped approach to allergy treatment. First, test to identify all your allergic triggers and try to lower or get rid of your exposure to them. Next, use over-the-counter allergy medications, which include steroid and antihistamine nasal sprays and antihistamine pills.

content_blocks.text: A doctor may suggest a stepped approach to allergy treatment. First, test to identify all your allergic triggers and try to lower or get rid of your exposure to them. Next, use over-the-counter allergy medications, which include steroid and antihistamine nasal sprays and antihistamine pills.

content: “I tell patients to start the nasal spray before allergy season begins, like around Valentine’s Day, because they reach maximum efficacy after about two weeks of use,” Patel says. Finally, if over-the-counter meds don’t offer enough relief, it’s time to see a doctor. “If you’re taking medicine and it’s not helping or allergies are still affecting your day-to-day life, I would recommend you see an allergist,” Patel says. Doctors can prescribe allergy medications that may be stronger and more effective than what you can pick up on your own at the drugstore. For people whose allergy symptoms are not well controlled enough by these medications, doctors may recommend allergy shots. Also known as allergen immunotherapy injections, each shot contains a tiny amount of the offending allergen. When it enters your system, it teaches your immune system to stop having its typical outsized reaction to the substance. But it takes a while to retrain the immune system. You must get the shots once or twice a week for the first six months and then monthly for a total of three to five years.

content: Huddleston is early in that process now. “I kept putting it off and putting it off, and my allergies kept getting worse,” he says. “I’d tell others with severe seasonal allergies, ‘Don’t be like me. Get to the allergist sooner rather than later.’”

sources: Deepti Manian, MD, allergist/immunologist, Topeka, Kansas.
meta_description: For some people, seasonal allergies come with asthma, insomnia, chronic infections, and a host of other year-round allergies.
